content: Is it possible to make an expression n with elaborated type Nat such that n is defeq to n+1?
only in an inconsistent context
yes, in an inconsistent context
I think it's probably possible

Well,

example (n : Nat) : haveI : Add Nat := âŸ¨fun a _ => aâŸ©;
    n = n + 1 :=
  rfl

but I don't think the same is possible if you said n.succ

theorem k (h : False) : âˆƒ n, n = n + 1 :=
  âŸ¨@Acc.rec Nat (fun _ _ => False) (fun _ _ => Nat)
    (fun x hx ih => ih x h + 1) 0 h.elim, by
  conv => lhs; rhs; change Acc.intro 0 h.elimâŸ©

/--
info: fun h =>
  Exists.intro (Acc.rec (fun x hx ih => Nat.succ (ih x h)) (False.rec (fun x => Acc (fun x x => False) 0) h))
    (Eq.refl
      (Acc.rec (fun x hx ih => Nat.succ (ih x h))
          (False.rec (fun x => âˆ€ (y : Nat), False â†’ Acc (fun x x => False) y) h 0 h)).succ)
-/
#guard_msgs in
#reduce (proofs := true) (types := true) k
for some reason rfl didn't work
but these are all defeq transformations
you can even see #reduce gives you Eq.refl

It might be a little more compelling if it weren't in an Exists.

However, I'm getting a kernel type error with this:

noncomputable def bad_n (h : False) : Nat :=
  @Acc.rec Nat (fun _ _ => False) (fun _ _ => Nat)
    (fun x _ ih => ih x h.elim + 1) 0 (Acc.intro 0 h.elim)

example (h : False) :
    bad_n h = bad_n h + 1 := by
  delta bad_n
  conv => lhs; rhs; change Acc.intro 0 h.elim

theorem k (h : False) :
  @Acc.rec Nat (fun _ _ => False) (fun _ _ => Nat)
    (fun x hx ih => ih x h + 1) 0 h.elim =
  @Acc.rec Nat (fun _ _ => False) (fun _ _ => Nat)
    (fun x hx ih => ih x h + 1) 0 h.elim + 1 := by
  conv => lhs; rhs; change Acc.intro 0 h.elim

/--
info: fun h =>
  Eq.refl
    (Acc.rec (fun x hx ih => Nat.succ (ih x h))
        (False.rec (fun x => âˆ€ (y : Nat), False â†’ Acc (fun x x => False) y) h 0 h)).succ
-/
#guard_msgs in
#reduce (proofs := true) (types := true) k
you have to be careful around the kernel here
since it can sometimes just decide not to iota reduce your Acc.rec
i mean, acc.rec is well-known to be evil

noncomputable def inf : Acc (fun _ _ => True) () â†’ Nat := Acc.rec fun _ _ ih => ih () âŸ¨âŸ© + 1

example : inf h = inf h + 1 := @id (inf h = inf âŸ¨_, fun _ _ => hâŸ©) rfl
-- example : inf h = inf h + 1 := rfl -- fails

-- https://arxiv.org/abs/1911.08174
def F : Prop := âˆ€ p, (p â†’ p) â†’ p
def Î´ (z : F) : F := fun p Î· => Î· (z (F â†’ F) id z p Î·)
def Ï‰ (h : âˆ€ p q : Prop, p = q) : F := fun p _ => h (F â†’ F) p â–¸ Î´
def Î© (h : âˆ€ p q : Prop, p = q) : Acc (fun _ _ => True) () := Î´ (Ï‰ h) (Acc (fun _ _ => True) ()) (âŸ¨_, fun _ _ => Â·âŸ©)

example : inf (Î© h) = inf (Î© h) + 1 := rfl

oh you can make it run for a while

set_option maxRecDepth 10000 in
example : inf (Î© h) = inf (Î© h) + 1000 := rfl

oh you can make it run forever

set_option maxRecDepth 0 in
example {n : Nat} : inf (Î© h) = inf (Î© h) + n := rfl
wow, someone dug into the arXivs
I think I remember seeing something like this before
oh I found it: #general > Normalization fails in lean @ ðŸ’¬
Interesting exploration of how inconsistent contexts and Acc.rec tricks can yield n = n + 1 in Lean. You may try searching on LeanFinder: www.leanfinder.org.
@leanfinder Lean proofs and examples showing n = n + 1 via inconsistent contexts, Acc.rec, and normalization quirks.

Hereâ€™s what I found:

  • lemma rec_add_one {C : â„• â†’ Sort*} (h0 : C 0) (h : âˆ€ n, C n â†’ C (n + 1)) (n : â„•) : Nat.rec h0 h (n + 1) = h n (Nat.rec h0 h n) := rfl "For any type family C:Nâ†’Sortâˆ—C : \mathbb{N} \to \text{Sort}^*C:Nâ†’Sortâˆ— and given:

  • A base case h0:C(0)h_0 : C(0)h0â€‹:C(0)

  • An inductive step function h:âˆ€n,C(n)â†’C(n+1)h : \forall n, C(n) \to C(n+1)h:âˆ€n,C(n)â†’C(n+1)

The recursion principle Nat.rec evaluated at n+1n+1n+1 satisfies Nat.recÂ h0Â hÂ (n+1)=h(n,Nat.recÂ h0Â hÂ n)\text{Nat.rec}\ h_0\ h\ (n+1) = h(n, \text{Nat.rec}\ h_0\ h\ n)Nat.recÂ h0â€‹Â hÂ (n+1)=h(n,Nat.recÂ h0â€‹Â hÂ n). This means that the value at n+1n+1n+1 is obtained by applying the step function hhh to nnn and the recursively computed value at nnn. " (score: 0.683)

  • theorem rec_eq_recC : @Acc.rec = @Acc.recC := by funext Î± r motive intro a t induction t with | intro x h ih => dsimp only [recC_intro intro h] congr; funext y hr; exact ih _ hr "The theorem states that the recursive function \texttt{Acc.rec} is equal to \texttt{Acc.recC}. This is shown by using function extensionality and induction on the accessibility predicate. Specifically, for a type Î±\alphaÎ±, a relation rrr, and a motive, the functions are equal for any accessible element aaa and its proof ttt. The proof proceeds by induction on ttt, showing that the two functions produce the same result by congruence and function extensionality." (score: 0.683)

  • theorem ndrec_eq_ndrecC : @Acc.ndrec = @Acc.ndrecC := by funext Î± r motive intro a t rw [Acc.ndrec, rec_eq_recC, Acc.ndrecC] "The recursion principle Acc.ndrec is equal to the computable version Acc.ndrecC for accessible elements." (score: 0.679)

  • theorem Nat.rec_add_one {C : â„• â†’ Sort*} (h0 : C 0) (h : âˆ€ n, C n â†’ C (n + 1)) (n : â„•) : Nat.rec h0 h (n + 1) = h n (Nat.rec h0 h n) := rfl "For any type family C:Nâ†’Sortâˆ—C : \mathbb{N} \to \text{Sort}^*C:Nâ†’Sortâˆ—, given a base case h0:C(0)h_0 : C(0)h0â€‹:C(0) and a step function h:âˆ€n,C(n)â†’C(n+1)h : \forall n, C(n) \to C(n+1)h:âˆ€n,C(n)â†’C(n+1), the recursive computation of CCC at n+1n+1n+1 satisfies rec(h0,h,n+1)=h(n,rec(h0,h,n))\text{rec}(h_0, h, n+1) = h(n, \text{rec}(h_0, h, n))rec(h0â€‹,h,n+1)=h(n,rec(h0â€‹,h,n))." (score: 0.678)

  • @[simp] lemma rec_one {C : â„• â†’ Sort*} (h0 : C 0) (h : âˆ€ n, C n â†’ C (n + 1)) : Nat.rec (motive := C) h0 h 1 = h 0 h0 := rfl "For any type family C:Nâ†’Sortâˆ—C : \mathbb{N} \to \text{Sort}^*C:Nâ†’Sortâˆ— and given:

  • A base case h0:C(0)h_0 : C(0)h0â€‹:C(0)

  • An inductive step function h:âˆ€n,C(n)â†’C(n+1)h : \forall n, C(n) \to C(n+1)h:âˆ€n,C(n)â†’C(n+1)

The recursion principle Nat.rec evaluated at one satisfies Nat.recÂ h0Â hÂ 1=h(0,h0)\text{Nat.rec}\ h_0\ h\ 1 = h(0, h_0)Nat.recÂ h0â€‹Â hÂ 1=h(0,h0â€‹). This means that starting from the base case h0h_0h0â€‹, applying the inductive step function once results in h(0,h0)h(0, h_0)h(0,h0â€‹). " (score: 0.677)

  • theorem ndrecOn_eq_ndrecOnC : @Acc.ndrecOn = @Acc.ndrecOnC := by funext Î± r motive intro a t rw [Acc.ndrecOn, rec_eq_recC, Acc.ndrecOnC] "The recursion principle Acc.ndrecOn is equal to the computable version Acc.ndrecOnC. This equality holds for any type Î±\alphaÎ±, relation rrr, and motive." (score: 0.675)

  • lemma leRecOn_self {C : â„• â†’ Sort*} {n} {next : âˆ€ {k}, C k â†’ C (k + 1)} (x : C n) : (leRecOn n.le_refl next x : C n) = x := leRec_self _ _ "For any type family C:Nâ†’Sortâˆ—C : \mathbb{N} \to \text{Sort}^*C:Nâ†’Sortâˆ—, natural number nnn, and step function next:âˆ€k,C(k)â†’C(k+1)\text{next} : \forall k, C(k) \to C(k+1)next:âˆ€k,C(k)â†’C(k+1), applying the recursion principle with initial value xâˆˆC(n)x \in C(n)xâˆˆC(n) when nâ‰¤nn \leq nnâ‰¤n yields:
    leRecOn(nâ‰¤n,next,x)=x \text{leRecOn}(n \leq n, \text{next}, x) = x leRecOn(nâ‰¤n,next,x)=x
    where the result is of type C(n)C(n)C(n). This establishes the base case for recursion." (score: 0.673)

  • lemma not_succ_lt_self : Â¬ succ n < n := Nat.not_lt_of_ge n.le_succ "For any natural number nnn, the successor of nnn is not less than nnn, i.e., Â¬(n+1<n)\neg (n + 1 < n)Â¬(n+1<n). This follows from the fact that nâ‰¤n+1n \leq n + 1nâ‰¤n+1." (score: 0.672)

  • theorem Nat.rec_one {C : â„• â†’ Sort*} (h0 : C 0) (h : âˆ€ n, C n â†’ C (n + 1)) : Nat.rec (motive := C) h0 h 1 = h 0 h0 := rfl "For any type family C:Nâ†’Sortâˆ—C : \mathbb{N} \to \text{Sort}^*C:Nâ†’Sortâˆ—, base case h0:C(0)h_0 : C(0)h0â€‹:C(0), and inductive step function h:âˆ€n,C(n)â†’C(n+1)h : \forall n, C(n) \to C(n+1)h:âˆ€n,C(n)â†’C(n+1), the recursion principle applied to 111 satisfies Nat.recÂ h0Â hÂ 1=hÂ 0Â h0\text{Nat.rec}\ h_0\ h\ 1 = h\ 0\ h_0Nat.recÂ h0â€‹Â hÂ 1=hÂ 0Â h0â€‹." (score: 0.671)
  • theorem PFunctor.M.agree'_refl {n : â„•} (x : M F) : Agree' n x x := by induction' n with _ n_ih generalizing x <;> induction x using PFunctor.M.casesOn' <;> constructor <;> try rfl intros apply n_ih "For any natural number nnn and any element xxx of the M-type Mâ€‰F\mathsf{M}\,FMF (the final coalgebra of a polynomial functor FFF), the depth-nnn agreement relation Agreeâ€™â€‰nâ€‰xâ€‰x\text{Agree'}\,n\,x\,xAgreeâ€™nxx holds. That is, any tree is identical to itself up to any depth nnn." (score: 0.669)
